conservatory.performanceDescription: Immerse yourself within London producer Kwesi Sey’s aka [o=o] aka kwes. first new music since his award-winning score to Raine Allen-Miller’s feature film Rye Lane. This brand new album premieres here, offers an intimate listening experience beginning at the entrance of the conservatory in small groups, beginning every hour on the hour.

cinema.performanceDescription: digging deep into the Warp archives to screen a curated selection of iconic and rare music videos spanning the label’s history, this collection features iconic work from Chris Cunningham, The Daniels, Andrew Norman Wilson, Jarvis Cocker, Alex Rutherford, and Hiro Murai and many more— all screened from the original master tapes.
cinema.performer: Warp Vision: Selected Music Video & Experimental Shorts : Hosted by Deeper Than Movies

act_1.artistBio: Freeka Tet is a French-born, New York City-based digital artist and creative mercenary working in the realm of experimental art. His practice combines objects, prosthetics, animatronics, hacking, coding, electronics, audio & video plunderphonics, bricolage, and performance-based work.

A British electronic and post-rock band formed in the early 1990s by Mark Clifford (guitar, programming), Daren Seymour (bass), Justin Fletcher (drums, programming), and Sarah Peacock (vocals, guitar). Breaking a thirteen-year hiatus, Seefeel released Everything Squared to critical acclaim in 2024, continuing to plow deeper and deeper still.
act_1.performanceDescription: In this special show, the band will premiere new music and prove why they have earned their place in the canon of British experimental music.

act_1.artistBio: An undeniable new talent, Clarissa Connelly is a conduit for timeless songs that feel more channelled than written. Premiering new repertoire, she will be joined here by a fourpiece band of live drums, recorder and guitar. Connelly herself playing guitar, piano and synthesiser.

act_2.artistBio: a British contemporary artist. His found object art and video pieces incorporate themes of nostalgia and anxiety, and draw on elements of pop culture, spanning several works and exhibitions. His performances have been presented in New York City at the Museum of Modern Art, Abrons Arts Center; at the Institute of Contemporary Arts, London, both in 2009; and at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, New York City, in 2008.
act_2.performanceDescription: In this brand new premiere, Leckey evokes incantations on the mic, while music, film and performance mesh on stage

act_2.artistBio: aka Jasper Marsalis - an artist and musician who explores the intersections of popular music and avant-garde performance; working across painting, sculpture, sound, code and text. Not the first musician to carry the surname Marsalis, Jasper made a name for himself by the moniker Slauson Malone (now Slauson Malone I) on ambitious releases that span myriad styles.
act_2.performanceDescription: Live at Barbican, Marsalis plays guitar, vocal and original programming, alongside cellist Nicky Wetherell. The duo share a rare, unspoken shorthand - layering dissonant sounds on top of one another to create a dense and dizzying suite of sonic collages

act_2.artistBio: an American experimental rock group, founded in 2002 in New York City by guitarist and keyboardist Ian Williams (formerly of Don Caballero and Storm & Stress) & drummer John Stanier (formerly of Helmet, Tomahawk and The Mark of Cain). The band is regarded as one of the most innovative rock bands of this century. In 2025 we find the band with renewed purpose, recording a new album and playing harder than ever before.

act_3.artistBio: aka Joshua Leary is an English electronic music producer & DJ from Ellesmere Port. Leary synthesises textures of trance break-downs and ambient music, with the dynamics of modern hip hop production. Undercutting his music is a power and dissonance evocative of EBM, Autechre, Jungle and Drone, but these are not things Leary talks about.
act_3.performanceDescription: For this unique show, Leary is re-tooling a live show with longtime collaborator Emannuel Baird, setting new focus points for strobe and parallel beams to illuminate clouds of haze above the auditorium. It is a show which denies photography and demands a body.
